Class Enemy

  • java.lang.Object
    • greenfoot.Actor
      • SuperSmoothMover
        • Entity
          • Enemy
  • public abstract class Enemy
extends Entity
    The Enemy abstract superclass controls all the entities in the game world that are not Villagers. In brief, they provide an adversarial function against the Villagers, and are usually hostile or targettable by and towards Villagers. Comes with its own sprite implementation, multiple helpful methods, and Villager targetting mechanisms.
    Version:
    3.00
    Author:
    Arthur Zeng and Michael Liu

    • Constructor Detail

      • Enemy

        public Enemy​(int maxSpeed,
             int maxHp,
             int direction)
        The Enemy constructor inherits the Entity constructor and passes its parameters into it as well. It also sets the false default values the variable that determines if the Enemy is being targetted by an archer.
        Parameters:
        maxSpeed - max speed of the spawned entity
        maxHp - max health of the spawned entity
        direction - either 1 (right), -1 (left), 2 (up), or -2 (down), determining the direction of the entity upon initial spawning

    • Method Detail

      • die

        public void die()
        Override of the inherited die() method that also incremeents the static variable enemiesKilled for usage in stat tracking.
        Overrides:
        die in class Entity

      • enemiesKilled

        public static int enemiesKilled()
        Returns the static variable enemiesKilled, aka how many enemies have died.
        Returns:
        static enemiesKilled

      • attackCycle

        public void attackCycle​(java.util.ArrayList<greenfoot.GreenfootImage> array,
                        int a,
                        int b,
                        int c,
                        int d)
        A clone of the cycle method from Entity adapted for the Enemy's 4-sprite based animation cycle. As such, it only cycles through four sprites at a time, and only has four parameters
        Parameters:
        array - the array of GreenfootImages you want to cycle through
        a - index of the first sprite you want to cycle
        b - index of the second sprite you want to cycle
        c - index of the third sprite you want to cycle
        d - index of the fourth sprite you want to cycle

      • movementAnimation

        public void movementAnimation()
        A modification of the movementAnimation() method from Entity, overridden here to match with the Enemy's cycle method, as well as their lack of sprites for moving up and down.
        Overrides:
        movementAnimation in class Entity

      • walk

        public void walk()
        A modification of the walk() method from Entity, overridden here to match with the Enemy's cycle method, as well as their lack of sprites for moving up and down.
        Overrides:
        walk in class Entity

      • findTarget

        public void findTarget()
        A small method that quickly finds any villager within a range of 2000 and designates that one as the 'target'. The 'target' variable is used in a variety of different behaviours for the Enemy, but is more or less the one the Enemy tries to attack and seek out at most times.

      • act

        public void act()
        Enemy's act() method only calls super.act(), which in itself is in Entity, and calls the walk() method.
        Overrides:
        act in class Entity

      • becomeTarget

        public void becomeTarget()
        Mutator of the targetOfArcher variable, determining whether an archer is targetting the Enemy. Sets it to true.

      • becomeNotTarget

        public void becomeNotTarget()
        Mutator of the targetOfArcher variable, determining whether an archer is targetting the Enemy. Sets it to false.

      • targettable

        public boolean targettable()
        Getter of the targetOfArcher variable, determining whether an archer is targetting the Enemy.
        Returns:
        targetOfArcher a variable representing whether or not the Enemy is a target of a villager archer.
